campsites.name: Muir Gorge of the Grand Canyon of the Tuolumne

description.cancellation_policy:
Cancellation Policy: Reservations cannot be sold and are non-transferable. Only the group leader or listed alternate can pick up or use the permit. Leader or alternate leader names cannot be changed or added.

You may cancel your reservation online at least 14 days before your entry date to receive a full refund of the recreation fees (reservation fee is non-refundable).

Change Policy:

  • Changes to group size can be made if quota space is available.
  • Change of entry trail, entry date, or permit type requires a new reservation for the desired trip. Recreation and reservation fees apply.
  • Changes to itinerary, exit date or exit location can be done online anytime or when the permit is issued.

Login to your account at Recreation.gov to make changes or call the Bridgeport District office for reservation assistance, (760) 932-7070.
description.description:
Bordering Yosemite National Park along the Pacific Crest and falling away to the Great Basin to the east, the Hoover Wilderness is a spectacular piece of Californiaâ€™s Sierra Nevada mountain range. Soaring peaks, glistening lakes and lush meadows are just some of its awesome spectacles. The headwaters of the East Walker River can also be found in the creeks of the Hoover Wilderness.

The Hoover was one of the original units of the National Wilderness Preservation System. It was established as a Primitive Area in 1931, then as a Wild Area in 1957. In 1964, Congress designated it as a Wilderness Area. It now has a total of 128,000 acres.

Trips beginning on Hoover Wilderness may continue into the wilderness areas of Yosemite National Park, Stanislaus and Inyo National Forests. However, in order to continue south of Highway 120 you must obtain another permit from the relevent authority that pertains to that entry point.Â 

As you plan your trip, remember that we must take care of this amazing place. While you are here, be respectful. Travel lightly on the land. Remember to leave this place undamaged so it will continue to be what we seek of wilderness. Hoover Wilderness is an ideal place for hiking and has some of the most spectacular high alpine landscape in the Sierra. Try to leave no trace of your passing.

All overnight trips into the Hoover Wilderness require a wilderness permit, year-round. All wilderness visitors, including day users, are encouraged to Call the ranger station for current information.Â
description.discounts:
There are no discounts.

National Interagency Passes are not accepted for wilderness permits.
description.driving_directions:
Bridgeport Ranger Station is located a 1/2 mile south of the town of Bridgeport, CA on Highway 395.

Directions to each trail can be found on the Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest webpage under hiking and the trail name.
description.fee_policy:
Reservation Fee:

A $6.00 non-refundable reservation fee is required for each permit.

Recreation Fee:

A $3.00 per person recreation fee is charged for your group when reserving a wilderness permit for entry on Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest trails in the Hoover Wilderness. The recreation fees are used to finance the on-the-ground wilderness programs on Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest.

Fees cannot be transferred to other dates or trails. No rain checks or credits.
description.need_to_know_email:
Printing Permits

Reserved permits will be available to print at home within seven days of the entry date. Please check your recreation.gov account as your entry date approaches. Once your permit is printed to PDF no changes can be made. You are responsible for the printing of your permit and are required to have a signed hardcopy for the duration of your trip. YOU DO NOT NEED TO GO TO THE RANGER STATION TO PICK UP YOUR PERMIT. IT IS YOUR RESPONSIBILITY TO PRINT FROM HOME OR ANOTHER PUBILC LOCATION (NOT THE RANGER STATION).

Permit Holder Responsibilities

  • Signed permit must be in the group leaderâ€™s possession.
  • Everyone in the group must start on entry date and location on permit.
  • You cannot exceed the group size stated on permit.
  • Groups cannot combine to exceed 15 people. In the Sawtooth Ridge Area, the maximum group size is 8.
  • Permit is valid for continuous wilderness travel. Exiting the wilderness and reentering at a different location voids permit.
  • Permit expires after exit date.Â 
  • Not all locations allow pets, including Yosemite National Park. It is your responsibility to ensure pets are allowed along your route.

Cancellation Policy

Reservations cannot be sold and are non-transferable. Only the group leader or listed alternate can use the permit. Leader or alternate leader names cannot be changed or added.

You may cancel your reservation online at least 14 days before your entry date to receive a full refund of the recreation fees (reservation fee is non-refundable).Â Â 

Change Policy

  • Changes to group size can be made if quota space is available.
  • Change of entry trail, entry date, or permit type requires a new reservation for the desired trip. Recreation and reservation fees apply.
  • Changes to itinerary, exit date or exit location can be done online.Â Â 
  • Once your permit is printed to PDF the permit is final and no changes can be made.
description.need_to_know_order:
Reserved permits will be emailed or made available to print at home within seven days of the entry date. Please watch for an email and check your recreation.gov account as your entry date approaches.Â 

Permit Holder Responsibilities

  • Signed permit must be in the group leaderâ€™s possession.
  • Group must start on entry date and location on permit.
  • Do not exceed the group size on permit.
  • Permit is valid for continuous wilderness travel. Exiting wilderness and reentering voids permit.
  • Permit expires after exit date.

Rules & Regulations for Hoover Wilderness

  • Pets are not allowed in Yosemite.
  • Store food properly so that it cannot be obtained by bears or other wildlife. Approved bear-resistant canisters are required.
  • Max group size is 15 people; no more than 25 head of stock.
  • Don't camp within 100 ft. of any lake shore, stream, or trail. If terrain does not permit camping at least 100 ft. away, camp no less than 25 ft. away in any situation.
  • Don't camp within 1/4 mile of Barney Lake for more than one consecutive night. Don't camp within 100 feet of the shore of Barney Lake.
  • No camping at Red, Blue, and Big Virginia lakes.
  • No campfires, stove fires or barbecues (or any fire that uses wood or charcoal), except for a portable stove using gas, jellied petroleum or pressurized fuel, within 1/4 mile of Barney Lake or Peeler Lake and above 9000 ft. within the Virginia Creek and Green Creek drainages.
  • Don't discharge a firearm, air rifle, or gas gun except for emergencies, or the taking of wildlife as permitted by state law.
  • Don't cut/damage standing trees, live or dead.
  • Camping is allowed for no more than 14 consecutive days.
  • It's illegal to possess or use a bicycle, wagon, cart, or other vehicle.
  • It's illegal to possess or use any motorized or mechanized equipment, including chainsaws.

Rules & Regulations for Sawtooth Ridge Zone

  • No campfires (no wood or charcoal fire).
  • Max group size is 8 persons, and no stock.
  • Don't camp within 100 yards of established routes.
description.need_to_know_pdf:
Permit Holder Responsibilities

  • Signed permit must be in the group leaderâ€™s possession.
  • Everyone in the group must start on entry date and location on permit.
  • You cannot exceed the group size stated on permit.
  • Groups cannot combine to exceed 15 people. In the Sawtooth Ridge Area, the maximum group size is 8.
  • Permit is valid for continuous wilderness travel. Exiting the wilderness and reentering at a different location voids permit.
  • Permit expires after exit date.

Review group size limits, food storage, pets, camping and campfire regulations for each area you will pass through. Youmust follow rules for each area while you are there.

Rules & Regulations For Hoover Wilderness

  • Please store your food properly so that it cannot be obtained by bears or other wild animals. Approved bear-resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed. Cleanup of food and debris if a bear gets into your food is your responsibility.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Maximum group size is 15 people; you can travel with no more than 25 head of stock.
  • Do not camp within 100 feet of any lake shore, stream, or trail. If terrain does not permit camping at least 100 feet away, camp no less than 25 feet away in any situation.
  • Do not camp within 1/4 mile of Barney Lake for more than one consecutive night. Do not camp within 100 feet of the shore of Barney Lake.
  • There is no camping at Red, Blue, and Big Virginia lakes.
  • Do not build, attend, maintain, or use a campfire, stove fire or barbecue (or any fire that uses wood or charcoal), except for a portable stove using gas, jellied petroleum or pressurized fuel, within 1/4 mile of Barney Lake or Peeler Lake and above 9000 feet within the Virginia Creek and Green Creek drainages.
  • Do not discharge a firearm, air rifle, or gas gun except for emergencies, or the taking of wildlife as permitted by state law.
  • Do not cut or damage standing trees, live or dead.
  • Camping is allowed for no more than 14 consecutive days.
  • It is illegal to possess or use a bicycle, wagon, cart, or other vehicle.
  • It is illegal to possess or use any motorized or mechanized equipment, including chainsaws.

Additional Rules & Regulations for the Sawtooth Ridge Zone

  • Do not build, maintain, or use a campfire (any wood or charcoal fire).
  • Maximum group size is 8 persons, and no stock.
  • Do not camp within 100 yards of established routes.
description.need_to_know_permit:
Printing Permits

Reserved permits will be emailed or made available to print at home within seven days of the entry date. Please look for an email and check your recreation.gov account as your entry date approaches. Once your permit is printed to PDF no changes can be made. You are required to have a signed hardcopy for the duration of your trip.

Permit Holder Responsibilities

  • A signed hard copy permit must be in the group leaderâ€™s possession.
  • Everyone in the group must start on entry date and location on permit.
  • You cannot exceed the group size stated on permit.
  • Groups cannot combine to exceed 15 people. In the Sawtooth Ridge Area, the maximum group size is 8.
  • Permit is valid for continuous wilderness travel. Exiting the wilderness and reentering at a different location voids permit.
  • Permit expires after exit date.

Review and follow group size limits, food storage, pets, camping and campfire regulations for each area you will pass through.Â 

Rules & Regulations For Hoover Wilderness

  • Not all locations allow pets, including Yosemite National Park. Ensure pets are allowed along your entire route.
  • Store your food properly so that it cannot be obtained by bears or other wild animals. Approved bear-resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed. Cleanup of food and debris if a bear gets into your food is your responsibility.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Maximum group size is 15 people; you can travel with no more than 25 head of stock.
  • Do not camp within 100 feet of any lake shore, stream, or trail. If terrain does not permit camping at least 100 feet away, camp no less than 25 feet away in any situation.
  • Do not camp within 1/4 mile of Barney Lake for more than one consecutive night. Do not camp within 100 feet of the shore of Barney Lake.
  • No camping at Red, Blue, and Big Virginia lakes.
  • Do not build, attend, maintain, or use a campfire, stove fire or barbecue (or any fire that uses wood or charcoal), except for a portable stove using gas, jellied petroleum or pressurized fuel, within 1/4 mile of Barney Lake or Peeler Lake and above 9000 feet within the Virginia Creek and Green Creek drainages.
  • Do not discharge a firearm, air rifle, or gas gun except for emergencies, or the taking of wildlife as permitted by state law.
  • Do not cut or damage standing trees, live or dead.
  • Camping is allowed for no more than 14 consecutive days.
  • It's illegal to possess or use a bicycle, wagon, cart, or other vehicle.
  • It's illegal to possess or use any motorized or mechanized equipment, including chainsaws.

Additional Rules & Regulations for the Sawtooth Ridge Zone

  • Do not build, maintain, or use a campfire (any wood or charcoal fire).
  • Maximum group size is 8 persons, and no stock.
  • Do not camp within 100 yards of established routes.

Human Waste Disposal

Human waste should be buried 6 to 8 inches deep and at least 200 feet from water sources, trails, or campsites.

Behave Responsibly

Respect other visitorâ€™s desire for quiet and solitude. Help protect this natural resource and leave it unmarked for future visitors. Familiarize yourself with Leave No Trace.

  • Pack out all your trash, help keep our wilderness areas pristine.
  • Protect water quality, donâ€™t use soap in natural waterways, even biodegradable soap can damage aquatic life. Waste water should be scattered at least 100 feet away from any water source.
  • Donâ€™t cut switchbacks, shortcutting damages the trail and adds to erosion.
  • No drones, they're prohibited in wilderness.
  • Don't camp on vegetation, these fragile areas are easily damaged.

Be Safe

  • Come prepared to find your way. Do not rely on cell phone for communication or navigation, most of the forest has no cell service.
  • Check weather and trail conditions.
  • Download maps, and emergency information before starting on the trail.
  • Plan to be self-sufficient, bring adequate supplies of food, water and clothing.
  • Learn symptoms of altitude sickness
description.no_show_policy:
Your reservation will be canceled and considered a no show and your space may go to other groups, unless you pick up your permit or arrange to hold the permit for late arrival before the deadline.

Deadline to Print your permit is 11 a.m. on the entry date.
description.quota_details:
Quota is available from the June 15th through October 15th.

Outside of this quota season; permits are self-issue or issued at the Bridgeport Ranger District office. The Sawtooth Ridge Zone continues with group size limitations.Â 

The number of people allowed to begin overnight trips is limited by quotas.

When selecting quota you are reserving a specific start date and entry trail. You only need space on the entry date.

  • If part of your group will enter on a different date or trail to meet you in the backcountry, they must have their own permit and fit into the quota.

Group size limits ensure people spread out to prevent impacts.

  • All ages count for group size/quotas.
  • Max group size is 15 people, except in the Sawtooth Ridge zone where the maximum group size is 8 people.

Groups on separate permits cannot combine if they exceed max group size.
description.season_information:
A wilderness permit is required year-round for the Hoover Wilderness. From June 15th through October 15, wilderness permits are limited by a trailhead quota. Each year quota season permits become available for advanced reservations six months in advance of your trip start day. During the quota season, up to one half of the wilderness permits for each trailhead will be made available within three days of the date of entry.

Reserved permits are available to print at home within 7 days of the entry date. Permits purchase within 3 days of the entry date will be immediately available for printing at home. Please check your recreation.gov account as your entry date approaches. You are responsible to print your permit and maintain a signed hard copy in your possession for the duration of your trip.

Trips sponsored by organizations or commercial groups must contact the Bridgeport Ranger District; a special use permit may be needed.

8560.description: The Buckeye Creek trail can lead you up and over Buckeye Pass into Kerrick Meadow and Rancheria Creek in Yosemite National Park or you can head northwest at the junction and along Kirkwood Creek to Kirkwood Pass and descend to the Upper West Walker River and Piute Meadows. To access the trail go through two gates and follow the dirt road for two miles to Big Meadows.  Then veer left and follow the trail for one mile in forest canopy. Cross Buckeye Creek and follow series of meadows and aspen groves to the wilderness boundary. Climb to The Roughs which is a spectacular canyon with steep cliffs and amazing views. This isnâ€™t a well-traveled trail and if you are looking for solitude this could be a good trail for you.

description_map.description: The Buckeye Creek trail can lead you up and over Buckeye Pass into Kerrick Meadow and Rancheria Creek in Yosemite National Park or you can head northwest at the junction and along Kirkwood Creek to Kirkwood Pass and descend to the Upper West Walker River and Piute Meadows. To access the trail go through two gates and follow the dirt road for two miles to Big Meadows. Then veer left and follow the trail for one mile in forest canopy. Cross Buckeye Creek and follow series of meadows and aspen groves to the wilderness boundary. Climb to The Roughs which is a spectacular canyon with steep cliffs and amazing views. This isnâ€™t a well-traveled trail and if you are looking for solitude this could be a good trail for you.
description_map.need_to_know:
• There is no potable water available at the campground and trailhead.
  • Stream crossings can be dangerous during high-water periods.
  • There is an active cattle allotment and cows can be present for the first several miles.
  • Bring plenty of water for the beginning miles as sources could be hard to get to or compromised by cattle grazing.
  • It can be difficult to find the proper trail through the meadows before you reach The Roughs, your goal is to reach the canyon opening on the far side of the meadows.
  • Follow all wilderness rules and regulations.

8560.name: Buckeye Creek

8561.description: Walk on mostly flat trail under the forest canopy for nearly two miles to several meadows with splendid views of Hunewill and Victoria Peaks to the north and Little Slide Canyon and Kettle Ridge to the south. Then climb moderate switchbacks for a long mile to reach Barney Lake.  Beyond Barney Lake the trail follows on flat granite benches for a mile and then climbs steeply to Crown and Peeler Lakes, with beautiful views of Slide Mountain and Crown Point. This is an extremely popular trail with opportunities to make a loop trail that accesses Yosemite National Park.

description_map.description: Walk on mostly flat trail under the forest canopy for nearly two miles to several meadows with splendid views of Hunewill and Victoria Peaks to the north and Little Slide Canyon and Kettle Ridge to the south. Then climb moderate switchbacks for a long mile to reach Barney Lake. Beyond Barney Lake the trail follows on flat granite benches for a mile and then climbs steeply to Crown and Peeler Lakes, with beautiful views of Slide Mountain and Crown Point. This is an extremely popular trail with opportunities to make a loop trail that accesses Yosemite National Park.
description_map.need_to_know:
In addition to the established wilderness rules:

  • Do not camp within 1/4 mile of Barney Lake for more than 1 consecutive night.
  • Do not build, attend, maintain, or use a campfire, stove fire or barbecue (or any fire that uses wood or charcoal), except for a portable stove using gas, jellied petroleum or pressurized fuel within 1/4 mile of Barney and Peeler Lakes.
  • Bear resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed. Cleanup of food and debris if a bear gets into your food is your responsibility.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Yosemite wilderness regulations apply if entering the National Park.

8561.name: Robinson Creek

8562.description: The route begins at the large boulder/lone tree in meadows nearly 2 miles from Mono Village up the Robinson Creek Trail.  Go south several hundred feet and cross Robinson Creek.  Climb the steep slope through dense forest for nearly a mile, then reach the open areas with over-rock travel up the steep canyon. Dramatic views and access to The Incredible Hulk await you. This area is extremely popular with climbers, please remember to leave no trace. Pack it in, pack it out.

description_map.description: The route begins at the large boulder/lone tree in meadows nearly 2 miles from Mono Village up the Robinson Creek Trail. Go south several hundred feet and cross Robinson Creek. Climb the steep slope through dense forest for nearly a mile, then reach the open areas with over-rock travel up the steep canyon. Dramatic views and access to The Incredible Hulk await you. This area is extremely popular with climbers, please remember to leave no trace. Pack it in, pack it out.
description_map.need_to_know:
In addition to the established wilderness rules, the following rules and regulations pertain to the Sawtooth Ridge Zone:

  • Do not build, maintain, or use a campfire (any wood or charcoal fire).
  • Maximum group size is 8 people, and no stock.
  • Do not camp within 100 yards of established routes.
  • Bear resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed. Cleanup of food and debris if a bear gets into your food is your responsibility.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Yosemite wilderness regulations apply if entering the National Park.

8562.name: Little Slide Canyon

8563.description: The trail climbs through switchbacks at various grades with some splendid views of Twin Lakes Basin.  Horsetail Falls is visible on exit from the forest less than two miles from the trailhead.  Above the falls the trail heads east to Cattle Creek or you can continue south up Horse Creek as it becomes a route at the small meadows by the wilderness boundary sign, that will reward you with outstanding views of Sawtooth Ridge and Matterhorn Peaks. There are plenty of rocks and scree to travel with views of steep canyon walls and peaks. The Horse Creek route is popular for experienced hikers, and is extremely popular with climbers, please remember to leave no trace. Pack it in, pack it out.

description_map.description: The trail climbs through switchbacks at various grades with some splendid views of Twin Lakes Basin. Horsetail Falls is visible on exit from the forest less than two miles from the trailhead. Above the falls the trail heads east to Cattle Creek or you can continue south up Horse Creek as it becomes a route at the small meadows by the wilderness boundary sign, that will reward you with outstanding views of Sawtooth Ridge and Matterhorn Peaks. There are plenty of rocks and scree to travel with views of steep canyon walls and peaks. The Horse Creek route is popular for experienced hikers, and is extremely popular with climbers, please remember to leave no trace. Pack it in, pack it out.
description_map.need_to_know:
In addition to the established wilderness rules, the following rules and regulations pertain to the Sawtooth Ridge Zone:

  • Do not build, maintain, or use a campfire (any wood or charcoal fire).
  • Maximum group size is 8 people, and no stock.
  • Do not camp within 100 yards of established routes.
  • Bear resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed. Cleanup of food and debris if a bear gets into your food is your responsibility.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Yosemite wilderness regulations apply if entering the National Park.

8563.name: Horse Creek

8564.description: You will follow a dirt road for a quarter mile before you start to climb nearly 1,000 feet over two demanding miles to Green Lake at just under 9,000 feet in elevation.  The main trail climbs steadily south to East Lake and Hoover Lakes and joins the trail to Summit Lake, and rewards you with outstanding mountain views. Heading west from Green Lake will take you to West Lake and routes to Bergona Lake and Par Value Lakes. Also to the west of Green Lake is an amazing route up Glines Canyon to Virginia Pass with fantastic views of many peaks in the norther Yosemite wilderness area.

description_map.description: You will follow a dirt road for a quarter mile before you start to climb nearly 1,000 feet over two demanding miles to Green Lake at just under 9,000 feet in elevation. The main trail climbs steadily south to East Lake and Hoover Lakes and joins the trail to Summit Lake, and rewards you with outstanding mountain views. Heading west from Green Lake will take you to West Lake and routes to Bergona Lake and Par Value Lakes. Also to the west of Green Lake is an amazing route up Glines Canyon to Virginia Pass with fantastic views of many peaks in the norther Yosemite wilderness area.
description_map.need_to_know:
In addition to the established wilderness rules:

  • Do not build, attend, maintain, or use a campfire, stove fire or barbecue (or any fire that uses wood or charcoal), except for a portable stove using gas, jellied petroleum or pressurized fuel above 9,000 feet within the Green Creek drainage.
  • No camping within 100 ft of any lake shore, stream, or developed trail.
  • Bear resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed. Cleanup of food and debris if a bear gets into your food is your responsibility.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Yosemite wilderness regulations apply if entering the National Park.

8564.name: Green Creek

8565.description: Starting at an elevation of nearly 10,000 feet the Virginia Lakes trail has stunning vistas, lakes and is a popular access point to the high backcountry of Yosemite National Park. Climb steadily for nearly three miles to the nameless pass at 11,000 feet and enjoy the spectacular views of the peaks and canyons of Hoover Wilderness and northern Yosemite National Park.

description_map.description: Starting at an elevation of nearly 10,000 feet the Virginia Lakes trail has stunning vistas, lakes and is a popular access point to the high backcountry of Yosemite National Park. Climb steadily for nearly three miles to the nameless pass at 11,000 feet and enjoy the spectacular views of the peaks and canyons of Hoover Wilderness and northern Yosemite National Park.
description_map.need_to_know:
In addition to the established wilderness rules:

  • Do not build, attend, maintain, or use a campfire, stove fire or barbecue (or any fire that uses wood or charcoal), except for a portable stove using gas, jellied petroleum or pressurized fuel above 9,000 feet within the Virginia Creek drainage.
  • No camping within 100 ft of any lake shore, stream, or developed trail.
  • There is no camping at Red Lake, Blue Lake, or Big Virginia Lake.
  • Bear resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Yosemite wilderness regulations apply if entering the National Park.

8565.name: Virginia Lakes

8566.description: Go south upstream for three miles through meadows and forest to Roosevelt and Lane Lakes. The West Walker Falls are an off trail jaunt less than a mile beyond Lane Lake. The main trail continues upstream through mostly total tree cover and minimal views for another four miles to the junction with trails to Piute Meadows or cross the stream to Fremont Lake and other wonderful lakes such as Chain of Lakes, Long Lakes, and Cinco Lake and the PCT. Upper Piute Meadows is a special place with amazing alpine views of Tower Peak and Hawksbeak Peak.

description_map.description: Go south upstream for three miles through meadows and forest to Roosevelt and Lane Lakes. The West Walker Falls are an off trail jaunt less than a mile beyond Lane Lake. The main trail continues upstream through mostly total tree cover and minimal views for another four miles to the junction with trails to Piute Meadows or cross the stream to Fremont Lake and other wonderful lakes such as Chain of Lakes, Long Lakes, and Cinco Lake and the PCT. Upper Piute Meadows is a special place with amazing alpine views of Tower Peak and Hawksbeak Peak.
description_map.need_to_know:
Use extreme caution crossing river and creeks during spring runoff.

In addition to the established wilderness rules:

  • No camping within 100 ft of any lake shore, stream, or developed trail.
  • Bear resistant food canisters are required in the Hoover Wilderness. Hanging or guarding of food items is not allowed. Cleanup of food and debris if a bear gets into your food is your responsibility.
  • Wilderness permits are required for all overnight use.
  • Yosemite wilderness regulations apply if entering the National Park.

8566.name: Leavitt Meadows

validations.name: IsBringingAnimalsEmpty
